items.content_html:
Fixes #3025

Primarily this removes the subnav heading, which does nothing. In addition there are some cases where the subnav heading indicates the existence of a quicklinks section for the sidebar. I have tried to make sure that the quicklinks are also removed if not relevant (used)
items.title: Fixes to subnav

items.content_html:
I recently came into an issue where I was trying to place a plain black bar using a sized gradient within the background of an element. However, because I wasn't setting the background-repeat property, it would just make the entire background black. Although the answer is obvious in hindsight, I think this bit of added guidance (perhaps with some slight tweaking to wording) would prevent quite a few head scratches.

Sentence inserted within the changed paragraph:

Additionally, if you do not specify the background-repeat property, the gradient will repeat across the element by default.

    • Provide a link to the issue(s) you are fixing, if appropriate, in the form "Fixes url-of-issue". GitHub will render this in the form "Fixes #1234", with the issue number linked to the issue. Doing this allows us to figure out what issues you are fixing, as well as helping to automate things (for example the issue will be closed once the PR that fixed it has been merged).
    • Review the results of the automated checking we run on every PR and fix any problems reported (see the list of checks near the bottom of the PR page). If you need help, please ask in a comment!

items.title: Provide some additional guidance on gradients

items.content_html:
The display of the formal syntax of CSS properties is currently broken, see mdn/yari#2963.

This change fixes the embedding of the {{csssyntax}} macro by removing the syntax highlighting from the surrounding <pre> element.

This change fixes mdn/yari#2963.

Sebastian
items.title: Corrected embedding of 'csssyntax' macro

items.content_html:
This should fail (eventually).

Simply loading <img src="workflow.svg"> in the HTML won't trigger a XSS risk except in some extremely old/odd clients like certain old HTML-enabled clients.
However, what an unsuspecting user might do is download the SVG or right-click and...

XSS:

We already check all .svg files for <script> tags but let's also check on on* handlers.
items.title: unsafe SVG files with on* handlers

items.content_html:
Summary of changes

Changed compatibility data source on this page from svg.attributes.presentation.stop-opacity to svg.elements.stop.stop-opacity.

This is following the suggestion that SVG compatibility data should be organized the same way HTML is: mdn/browser-compat-data#9462

Which in turn is following discussion here about missing compatibility data for stop-opacity: mdn/browser-compat-data#9402
items.title: Switch to different svg compat data (mdn/browser-compat-data#9402)

items.content_html:
In my opinion, Object.prototype.__noSuchMethod__, Object.prototype.unwatch(), and Object.prototype.watch() in Object page should be removed.

Reasons being that the links are broken due to the pages being archived, there is a better alternative like Proxy, and they still can access the pages at Archived JavaScript Reference.

items.title: Remove obsolete property and methods

items.content_html:
The json() method of the Body mixin takes a Response stream and reads it to completion. It returns a promise that resolves with the result of parsing the body text as JSON.

can read like "It returns a promise that resolves ... as JSON"

but in fact, it means "It returns a promise that resolves with (the result of parsing the body text as JSON)"

So it is: by parsing the body text as JSON, return the result in the form of a JavaScript object.

It is mentioned as such down below the docs, but the title can give people wrong impressions that it is returning "JSON".

There are so many places where people think it is "JSON", when it is JavaScript object.

https://github.com/mdn/fetch-examples/blob/e59e035214d21926eb7fc474e0cea88b33199b00/fetch-json/index.html

and the pull request to correct it: mdn/fetch-examples#16

https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/

fetch('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/todos/1')
  .then(response => response.json())
  .then(json => console.log(json))

You see, we have a string s, we use parseInt(s) to get back an integer. We would not call that integer a string, would we?

So, we have JSON, we use .json() to parse it and get back a JavaScript object, and we call this JavaScript object a "JSON". That is very wrong.

    • Provide a link to the issue(s) you are fixing, if appropriate, in the form "Fixes url-of-issue". GitHub will render this in the form "Fixes #1234", with the issue number linked to the issue. Doing this allows us to figure out what issues you are fixing, as well as helping to automate things (for example the issue will be closed once the PR that fixed it has been merged).

items.content_html:
Another of the Trusted Type API interfaces. This time TrustedTypePolicy.

Spec: https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-trusted-types/dist/spec/#trusted-type-policy

Reviewer: @jpmedley
items.title: Adds TrustedTypePolicy API

items.content_html: This includes a few changes to the word 'favorite' because they were part of the same keyword or identifier is the primary issue of this PR.
items.title: Change spelling of 'color' to American spelling

items.content_html:
Working on documenting the Trusted Types API. This PR adds:

  • TrustedHTML
  • TrustedScript
  • TrustedScriptURL

Spec: https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-trusted-types/dist/spec/

Reviewer: @jpmedley

To save yourself some time Joe, these are all pretty much the same as each other so if you want to snag TrustedHTML and the two method pages, I will then apply any changes to the others.

Also, it looks as if toJSON() is only in Canary (I tested it), and we have no BCD for the method. So that will need adding, which I can do if it is going to land.
items.title: Adds TrustedHTML, TrustedScript, TrustedScriptURL
